title: Energy - energy of pendulum on different planet

content.description:
A pendulum consisting of a spherical mass at the end of a long string is suspended from a ceiling at the surface of Earth. The pendulum is displaced a small angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> from the vertical and released from rest. The kinetic energy of the sphere as it passes through the lowest point is <math alttext="K sub E" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></math>.

The pendulum is then taken to a planet where the gravitational field strength is approximately equal to half of the gravitational field strength on Earth. The pendulum is again suspended from a ceiling, displaced the same small angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"> <mi>θ</mi> </math>, and is released from rest. The kinetic energy of the sphere as it passes through its lowest point is <math alttext="K sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mstyle></math>.
content.question:
Which of the following correctly compares <math alttext="K sub E" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <msub> <mi>K</mi> <mi>E</mi> </msub> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="K sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mstyle></math>, and provides a correct justification?

Comparison
 Justification

A
 <math alttext="K sub p is less than K sub E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></mstyle></math>
 The total energy of the sphere-planet system is constant throughout the swing, and there is less potential energy in the sphere-planet system on the new planet.

B
 <math alttext="K sub p is less than K sub E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></mstyle></math>
 The total energy of the sphere-planet system is constant throughout the swing, but a smaller fraction of the total energy of the system is transformed into kinetic energy on the new planet.

C
 <math alttext="K sub p equals K sub E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></mstyle></math>
 The kinetic energy of the sphere is independent of the gravitational field strength.

D
 <math alttext="K sub p equals K sub E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></mstyle></math>
 The speed of the sphere is doubled, and the weight of the sphere is halved on the new planet, so the kinetic energies are equal.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
